SCF-DHS to provide DHS/FEMA with additional staff to augment existing cadres in the field Number of personnel required:7 
Specialty: As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will provide External Affairs/Intergovernmental Affairs (IGA) subject matter experts (SMEs) to the ESF-15 team in Florida. These SMEs will report directly to ESF-15 and will speak publicly on behalf of DHS and provide specialized expertise on the response and recovery mission in Florida. With the amount of municipalities included in the affected areas of Florida as a result of hurricane Ian, it is vital that we provide IGA liaisons to connect as soon as possible. These SMEs will be available to answer any questions they might receive from local officials, and also proactively provide important updates on federal assistance

The State of Louisiana requests ESF-10 assistance in response to Hurricane Laura with the assessment, removal and disposal of actual or potential discharges or releases of oil and hazardous materials, pollutants and contaminants in the impacted areas originating from the following sources:

1. Orphan Containers  A container of 5 gallons or larger including, but not limited to, a drum, tank, and/or cylinder, which contains oil and/or hazardous materials or other materials which could pose a hazard to the public or environment.

2. Vessels  Vessels which have been damaged or sunken and contain fluids which are or could pose a public health threat or hazard to the environment. In addition, vessels which are secured at a location and do not pose a public health threat or hazard to the environment will not be addressed by this scope of work. 
The State of Louisiana shall not contribute to the cost of any work commenced prior to FEMAs issuance of the mission assignment to the United States Coast Guard (USCG).

NIST is requested to provide observed windfield data in order to meet the programmatic requirements to include virtual PDAs.

Hurricane Laura has escalated into being a major Hurricane at landfall resulting in very high winds impacting the Beaumont , TX area with tropical storms winds expected in Baton Rouge, LA.  In order to support remote PDA needs, observed windfield data is necessary; however, typical methods (e.g., HAZUS) do not capture observations requiring NIST resources.

The state of New Mexico requests extension of Civil Air Patrol via new Mission Assignment from January 1, 2021 to for a period of 90 days to March 31, 2021 for continued support to COVID response. Projected operations will require a estimated cost increase of $24,000 to obligated funding. New Mission Assignment is required to facilitate funding compatibility with Civil Air Patrol accounting processes.

State of New Mexico requests activation and funding support for New Mexico Civil Air Patrol (NM CAP) Wing to conduct support flights as Air Force Assigned Missions consistent with National Civil Air Patrol FY2020 Operations Plan for COVID-19 Response and Recovery Operations. Primary support would be expedited transportation of COVID-19 test specimens/samples between collection site to State testing facilities. NM CAP would also assist with transportation of COVID-19 viral test kits from bulk inventories to points of distribution, testing locations, or other critical facilities. NM CAP support could also expedite distribution of equipment critical to COVID response or medical care. NM CAP will not transport COVID positive or suspected COVID positive patients. The complete scope of Missions is detailed in the Operations Plan, paragraphs 2.a. to 2.f.

NM CAP has pre-coordinated with NM National Guard and Department of Health, and agrees to this support as two concepts of operations where they can provide substantial positive impact to COVID-19 response in New Mexico:
A)	Urgent Request  Taskings that are considered time sensitive (less than 24-hour response).
B)	Planned Sustainment Operations  Conduct 1-2 planned taskings per week on a regular basis to supply remote, distant, or limited accessibility locations.

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: 
MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 
The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

The PA Department of Human Service (ESF #6 Mass Care Lead) is requesting a total of 300,000 DLA shelf stable Food Boxes (NOT MREs) for downrange distribution to local communities that are impacted by the social/economic effects of COVID 19. Many affected are suffering from food insecurity.

Commonwealth of PA DLA short shelf life Food Boxes 

Remarks:
This is a second request on the behalf of the PA Department of Human Service (ESF #6 Mass Care Lead) for an additional 437,000 DLA short shelf life Food Boxes for downrange distribution to local communities that are impacted by the social/economic effects of COVID 19. Many affected are suffering from food insecurity. (Quantity is based on a daily burn rate of approximately 31,000 meals per day X 14 days.  Food Boxes, available from the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA), will be used by local agencies, such as Local Area Agencies on Aging, Meals on Wheels, and County Action Committees to provide life sustaining nourishment for low income and atrisk populations. This includes children and elderly populations across the Commonwealth. These Food Boxes will be used to supplement already strained food supply chains that typically serve these populations (i.e., Salvation Army, Feeding PA Food Banks, and other communitybased feeding organizations). Rhode Island State Association of Firefighters and Providence Fire/Police, through RIEMA, are requesting 90,000 medical grade N95 masks that will be utilized by FIRE/EMS/POLICE throughout the State of Rhode Island.

Clarifying notes added by FEMA Region 1:
Request HHS provide 90,000 Surgical Grade N95 Respirators (3M model 1860 or Kimberly Clark equivalent model)

In order to support the FIRE/EMS/Police communities during COVID19, the State of Rhode Island is requesting ninety thousand (90,000) Surgical Grade N95 respirators from one of the following model options:
Respirators (L) 3M, PPE N95
RIEMA will also accept the Kimberly Clark surgical grade N95 models 46727 (size Regular) and 46827 (size Small), preferred ratio is majority model 46727 (size Regular). Send 90,000 quantity of model 46727 (size Regular) or include minority quantity of model 46827 (size Small).

NO SUBSTITUTIONS TO OTHER MODEL NUMBERS ARE DESIRED WITHOUT THE EXPRESSED CONSENT OF A STATE APPROVING AUTHORITY

Estimated Individual cost for 3M 1860 or equivalent Kimberly Clark Respirator= $0.56 plus $0.10 Transportation cost = $0.66 per respirator
$0.66 per respirator for 90,000 respirators equals estimated total cost $59,400.

Request HHS provide 25,000 Surgical Grade N95 Respirators (3M model 1860 or Kimberly Clark equivalent model)

In order to support the medical community during COVID19, the State of Rhode Island is requesting twenty-five thousand (25,000) Medical Grade N95 respirators from one of the following model options  

Respirators (L) 3M, PPE N95

RIEMA/RIDOH will also accept the Kimberly Clark surgical grade N95 models, preferred ratio:
Majority 46727
20,000 quantity of model 46727
5,000 quantity of model 46827
NO SUBSTITUTIONS TO OTHER MODEL NUMBERS ARE DESIRED WITHOUT THE EXPRESSED CONSENT OF A STATE APPROVING AUTHORITY

Estimated Individual cost for 3M 1860 or equivalent Kimberly Clark Respirator= $0.56 plus $0.10 Transportation cost = $0.66 per respirator
$0.66 per respirator for 25,000 respirators equals estimated total cost $16,500

**The National Response Coordination Center (NRCC) and National Mission Assignment Program Office has directed the Region to mission assign HHS to provide the Federal Medical Stations (FMS).**

INITIAL REQUEST:

The State of Rhode Island is requesting a federal medical station type capability, able to support a 250 bed configuration with medical supplies to support acute, non surgical, nontraumatic patients. This support will augment state and local medical response resources for immediate and short term needs. The facility is intended to support the Rhode Island Department of Health officially projected surge in COVID19 patients that will exceeded current hospital capability. This request is for EQUIPMENT ONLY. The state will provide facility medical staffing IAW established guidelines The ultimate intent of this RRF is to provide a similar facility capability to what is found in the FEMA PSMA ID HHS PSMA ESF873 (attached), with out the staffing outlined in the PSMA. This resource will be established at a venue (40,000sf+) currently being evaluated by the US Army Corps of Engineers under MATO to MA DC20030901COENAD02. Date/Time needed is an estimate based on the identification, provisioning and establishment of this facility as well as the attached medical surge modeling. Based on best estimates at this time, the requested date and time needed could move based on this variable. Delivery Site Location is currently listed as State Staging area and will be updated to the facility when USACE inspection is finished. THIS REQUEST IS IN ADDITION TO REQUEST FOR FMS (WITH STAFFING) SUBMITTED BY STATE ON RRF#: 2624-116650 Request is based on Rhode Island Department of Health Medical Surge Modeling that states they are currently in week 5 of the provided model and that this capability will be required to be IN PLACE AND OPERATIONAL when the state reaches to Level 3 (Catastrophic) impacts, currently projected to be on or about week 13, therefor the requested delivery date is for week 11. Full modeling and joint Rhode Island Emergency Management Agency/Rhode Island Department of Health justification, surge planning summary with decision points, triggers, planning considerations, gap analysis, staffing estimates and predictive models are attached to justify this request. The State of Rhode Island has a valid and executable plan and is requesting federal resources to fill the identified resource gap identified in the attached models and plans.

Rhode Island is requesting a small medical team or clinical extenders (DoD or other federal agency or contracted medical staff) to care for COVID positive patients to support Kent Hospital. Staff will provide direct clinical care and augment ED and med surge units for COVID+ patients and inpatients. Expected outcomes are increased throughput from the ED to inpatient beds, increased inpatient bed availability, reduced boarding times, and fewer necessary transfers to other hospitals. 

Full POP dates: 01/16/22 - 02/04/22
HMTF work dates at Kent Hospital: 01/19/22 - 02/01/22 (and travel days 01/18/22 and 02/02/22)

BOC2508- Request, in order to expand capacity at CHI-Mercy Medical Center, the sole community hospital in Roseburg Oregon to treat severely ill COVID-19, and other patients, we request that the VAMC Roseburg take civilian patients from the hospital and the community who require subacute or observation level care for COVID-19 and other conditions that would otherwise be admitted to the general medicine ward of Mercy Medical Center. 2. Justification  MMC cares for all severely ill and injured patients in the Roseburg catchment area, including VA patients. Existing protocols allow transfer of VA eligible patients whose level of care does not exceed the scope of services at VAMC Roseburg. In this emergency, it is estimated that 10-15% of additional bed capacity could be made available if civilian patients in Mercy Medical Center who are stable for transfer and do not exceed scope of care for VAMC given staffing levels for subacute care were able to be transferred from MMC to VAMC or diverted from the community for admission to VAMC directly.

The Governor is seeking Title 32 authorization to mobilize up to 1,250 members of the ORNG to support response activities such as supporting the Oregon Medical Station, PPE warehouse logistics and distribution, decompression efforts at hospitals, logistical support to Oregon Health Authority and Oregon Hospitals, and EOC support.

This Mission Assignment (MA) is for Title 32 reimbursement.

In accordance with Presidential Memorandum dated 4/7 (attached), individual Title 32 orders may be extended/issued for a total of 31 days, and must be issued no later than 4/21. As such, the period of performance of this MA is through May 22 and cost adjusted for 31-day deployment estimates, based on those parameters. Individual guardsmen will not exceed 31 days in T-32 status under this mission assignment. DOD will manage sourcing based on the authorized number of guard personnel to be employed for duty not to exceed 31 days

**The National Response Coordination Center (NRCC) and National Mission Assignment Program Office has directed the Region to mission assign HHS to provide the Federal Medical Stations (FMS).**

INITIAL REQUEST: 

Request for federal medical support stations or similar equipment packages to support areas where there are higher identified cases of COVID 19 and a lower quantity of hospital bed space/care options. The three initially requested locations are Berkshire, Springfield, and Plymouth. These are areas of the Commonwealth with significantly higher cases and limited medical capacity. In addition, the state has scoped the local communities for available hotel and dorm space to support the facilities but have had limited or minimal response in the area. Identified facilities to be supported and will provide staffing would be: Berkshire Medical Center, Baystate Health, and Beth Israel Deaconess - Plymouth.

Phase 1: Immediate Needs Request, due to the critical care staffing shortfall, GMH and the Guam State Surgeons Cell requests the immediate need for 2 Intensivists, 15 Nurses and 4 Respiratory Therapists. The State of Michigan is requesting two Type II Tailorable Vaccine Support Teams VST ISO Community Vaccination Centers (CVC)  at the Devos Place in Grand Rapids, MI and the TCF Center in Detroit. LAD April 23, FOC April 28. Michigan is experiencing an unprecedented surge in B117 CVID-19 cases. Clinical hospital personnel are currently staffing the Devos Place CVC, and the recent rise in cases is stressing current hospital capability. The support from DoD will assist in freeing up clinical personnel to return to the hospitals to address COVID-19 hospitalizations and urgent care needs, while also helping to enhance vaccine throughout at the location to slow the spread of COVID-19. DoD personnel onsite at the TCF center will enable current staff to shift operational focus to supporting mobile operations while also expanding overall throughput to slow the spread of COVID-19 in the Detroit area. DoD will provide critical resources to assist with state vaccination efforts at the DeVos Place in Grand Rapids, MI and TCF Center in Detroit,  starting April 21, 2021 through July 7, 2021. RDD 23 April FOC 28 April Last day shot in arms 22 June Travel out date 23 June as well. MATOs will be issued for each site and any others identified.

ADDITIONAL NOTES from FEMA: 
- MA task orders (MATOs) may be issued by FEMA for specific requirements, personnel, location(s), date(s), and duration of assignment(s). 
- Agencies will be reimbursed for all eligible expenses pursuant to 44 CFR. Supporting documentation is required for reimbursement. 
- All equipment and supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. If approved, documentation is necessary to ensure reimbursement. 
- Activation of agency command center(s), if required, must be coordinated with FEMA as a separate MA. 
- The mission-assigned agency is responsible for ensuring that all activity is properly authorized, goods are received, services are provided, and that costs are reasonable and supported by documentation maintained by the respective agency 
- MAs shall be considered for closure after 180 days with no financial activity in accordance with FEMA CFO Bulletin #157. For MAs still operationally open, requests for additional obligations may be withheld if no invoicing, ULO Validation, or additional justification has been provided.

ICATT - ARPA. State of Missouri requests HHS-CDC assistance implementing and managing COVID-19 surge testing sites.  This request meets the four criteria established in which surge testing sites should be considered for communities:

1) With moderate-to-high social vulnerability index1

2) Where the demographic composition of the sites surrounding county includes large minority or at risk populations 

3) Where the average COVID-19 incidence is 100 cases per 100,000 population over last 7 days

4) Where the percentage of COVID-19 fully vaccinated, among those eligible for vaccine, is less than the average U.S. percentage of fully vaccinated

ARPA VC This MA is being issued with funding through the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021.

The State of Illinois is requesting an extension of the current Incident Management Team (IMT) deployment through RRF# 48-7673, which provides federal support to the States mass vaccination planning and operational programs. The state of Illinois is seeking this command element to assist the State Emergency Operations Center (SEOC) in augmenting and providing technical assistance to existing personnel as the roles and responsibilities of the Vaccination LOE expand with the movement towards privatization at state/local fixed sites, expansion of mobile equity capabilities to high-SVI locations statewide, introduction of state/faith-based mobile capabilities, and continued operations of the United Center Mobile Equity Vaccination teams. IL focus on expanded planning support provided by the IMT includes continual planning for vaccinations using equity-based delivery and administration to undeserved and isolated rural communities. Illinois is requesting that the extension be for an additional 30-days beginning with the end date of the current IMT deployment. This request has been coordinated with the current IMT IC and FEMA LNO. Throughout the deployment of IMT in support of Illinois an evaluation will be completed to determine the need for an additional extension or demobilization of this resource. To ensure ongoing capabilities that the State cannot fill these critical roles and responsibilities through existing capability or contractual staffing. The State of Illinois request for an extension of support is for: IC, PIO, (2) Liaison, (2) OPS, (1) Operational Planner, (1) PSC), (1) SITL, (1) RESL, (1) LSC, (1) LOG Specialist, and (1) FINANCE Section Chief. OPERATIONAL SCHEDULE To continue operations and ensure continuity of operations throughout a transition we request the current IMT extend for a maximum of 5-days for transition of C2 and cross-orientation. This 5-day transition will allow the incoming IC with assigning and integrating positions pertaining to skillsets on the team. This will also allow for the incoming team to shadow current operations and familiarize with expectations and work projects. 4/13/21 update - RDD changed from 4/11 to 4/21 based on reasonable time for USCG to deliver staff.

ARPA-MMT - Clinical Personnel - Various

Deployment of 10 Acute Care Strike Teams (ACST) to provide medical staffing as required in the State of New Jersey in support of the COVID-19 pandemic. Each Strike Teams should consist of one (1) Doctor/ Physician (including intensivists, critical care, emergency medicine),  four (4) Nurses (including RNs in intensive care, critical care, ER, MedSurg and LPNs), four (4) Allied Health Professionals (including Respiratory therapists, lab technicians, radiology technicians), one (1) Pharmacy personnel (including pharmacies and pharmacist technicians), and five (5) Personal care technicians (patient assistants). 

Acute Care Strike Teams to be deployed regionally throughout the State. The State has organized its hospitals by region (North, Central, South) with each region coordinated by a Regional Collaborator (each from a Level 1 Trauma Hospital in NJ). The Regional Collaborators will move the Strike Teams within their respective region based on which hospitals have the greatest caseload and staffing shortages.

(SEE ORIGINAL RRF 2605-689222)

4 Embalmers, 2 for day shift and 2 for night shift. 

The Texas Panhandle area (TSA A and B) is seeing an increase of decedents needing to be processed. This increase combined with the fact that funeral home staff in this area are in short supply and have been impacted by COVID-19 themselves, is causing a back-log at funeral homes and hospitals. The total number of COVID deaths for the Texas Panhandle area (TSA A and B) is currently 870. Over the past month there have been 53 deaths in TSA-A, and 203 deaths in TSA-B, accounting for almost 30% of the total deaths for this area in just the past month alone. 

The Panhandle area needs additional embalmers to increase their capacity and relieve the back-log of decedents needing to be processed. 

Shafer Mortuary Services is the only provider of mortuary services in TSA A, covering 26 counties in the Panhandle, inciuding Amarillo. They are currently working twice their normal caseload. They currently only have 2 embalmers 
working (the owners). Other embalmers on staff are out with COVID or on maternity leave. They have been unable to hire any new staff and submitted a STAR request for 4 embalmers. The owners at Shafer have stated they are 
exhausted and desperately need help. Due to the fact that the owners are having to perform embalming services, administrative duties are being impacted which slows down other aspects of funeral services. 

DSHS has tried to source embalming staff from other areas in Texas but have been unsuccessful due to the high demand and low availability of these staff. DSHS asked Texas Funeral Directors Association, the Texas Funeral Service Commission and the Harris County Institute of Forensic Sciences to support this STAR and they were unable to provide embalmers. 

Shafer exceeded their cooler storage and currently have 2 FEMA trailers at their location, 1 is full with 48 cadavers waiting to be processed. Only one crematorium exists in the area that cremate a maximum of 5 decedents daily. There are currently 40 waiting for cremation. 

Surrounding funeral homes are at max capacity. The other nearest mortuary service is in Lubbock and they are also at max capacity and processing double than the normal caseload. They are currently able to maintain the workload due to having a larger facility, more staff and two crematoriums.

Louisiana request, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA) provide 16 med/surgical beds and 2 intensive care (ICU) beds at the Overton Brooks VA Medical Center in Shreveport, LA for immediate and short-term acute medical treatment. The work should include any or all the following VHA capabilities: 24 hour medical/administrative/support staff, medical/nonmedical equipment, sustenance, pharmaceuticals, supplies and ancillary serviced to care for critical, non-critical, COVID positive and non-COVID positive, non-Veteran patients.

The State of Louisiana is requesting the below staff to help augment the shortages in hospitals across Louisiana due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

200  RNs (Med Surge/ICU Step Down/ER experience required)
250 - ICU Nurses (ICU experienced required)
150  Patient Care Attendants/ Certified Nursing Assistance
30  LPNs 
10 - Lab Technicians
40 - Respiratory Therapy Technicians
10  Phlebotomist

Justification:

These numbers are based on our upward framing of hospital request.  Total staff requested will assist our four greatest impacted parishes augment staff lost due to COVID infections and increase their bed capacity to provide care for the increasing COVID admissions.  The nature of this pandemic has called for health care facilities to creatively support surge in COVID positive and PUIs patients, higher acuity levels with decreased nurse-patient ratios, Personal Protective Equipment Donning/Doffing requirements and limitations, frequency in environmental cleaning and decontamination.

Hospitals in Regions 2, 4, 5 (East Baton Rouge Parish, Lafayette Parish, Iberia Parish and Calcasieu Parish) need staffing for an additional 90 floor beds and an additional 66 ICU beds. Since July 1, 2020, Louisiana has added 23,953 COVID-19 cases, 570 hospitalizations with 65 additional on ventilators, and an additional 221 deaths. Our statewide numbers continue to rise daily and we anticipate possible additional healthcare staff shortages.

Louisiana request, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA) provide 16 med/surgical beds and 2 intensive care (ICU) beds at the Overton Brooks VA Medical Center in Shreveport, LA for immediate and short-term acute medical treatment. ARPA-VHA will assist State of Iowa COVID19 outbreak response operations by providing up to six (6) acute care (Medical/Surgical (M/S) and/or two (2) intensive care (ICU) beds, as necessary, at Veterans Integrated Service Network 23 facilities for critical or noncritical, non-COVID or COVID-positive, patients who are not eligible for such benefits. Facility assignment to be determined at time of transfer and is dependent on availability.

NOTE: bed costs are determined by M/S beds are $3,835 each per day and ICU are $6,485 each per day.

The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), Veterans Integrated Services Network 23: VA Midwest Health Care Network will assist State of Iowa COVID-19 outbreak response operations by providing staffing of healthcare personnel to support vulnerable residents/patients in the Iowa Veterans Home. This request includes up to twenty-one (21) Registered Nurses (RNs) OR Licensed Practical Nurses (LPNs) OR any combination thereof, per day. Services to be provided at the Iowa Veterans Home in Marshalltown, IA. The state has exhausted all other options for providers. Services to be provided until such support is obtained.

The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), Veterans Integrated Services Network 23: VA Midwest Health Care Network will assist State of Iowa COVID-19 outbreak response operations by providing staffing of healthcare personnel to support vulnerable residents/patients in the Iowa Veterans Home. This request includes up to four (4) Registered Nurses (RNs), sixteen (16) Licensed Practical Nurses (LPNs), and twenty-seven (27) Nursing Assistants or Health Technicians per day. Services to be provided at the Iowa Veterans Home in Marshalltown, IA. The state has exhausted all other options for providers. Services to be provided until such support is obtained.

VHA will assist State of Iowa COVID-19 outbreak response operations by providing up to twenty (20) acute care (M/S) or intensive care (ICU) beds, as necessary, at either the Des Moines VA Medical Center (VAMC) or Iowa City VAMC for non-COVID and COVID-positive patients who are not eligible for such benefits. Facility assignment to be determined at time of transfer and is dependent on availability.

NOTE: bed costs are determined by $6,485/bed/day

ARPA -ICATT- Mobile COVID-19 Testing Capability

New York State (DR-4480-NY) requests mobile testing units to support the intense surge in testing requirements related to increasing COVID-19 positivity and case rates from the Omnicron variant.

NYC is experiencing overwhelming increase in individuals seeking testing that has far exceeded current capabilities, triggered by the beginning of the Omicron wave and projected to sweep across the state especially in light of interconnection of commuter movement. Testing vans will be available at public locations, with special focus on areas most impacted: NYC has identified potential locations and NYS locations to include but not limited to public commuter parking facilities.

Units requested to include all needed supplies, vehicles, equipment, staff and management staff to conduct specimen collection, transportation to lab, and waste disposal.

ARPA - Medical Equipment: Dialysis Machines (Tablo) - QTY 15

NYS requests extension of presently deployed resources:
15 Tablo Dialysis machine systems and consumable bundles (PN - 1000480 - Treatment Bundle - Tablo Cartridge and Straws, PN-0000831 - Bicarb Concentrate, PN-0002630/832/833/631 - Acid Concentrate (choice of 1K, 2K, 3K, or 4K) from the SNS for up to 6 months with 0% non-federal cost share.
Due to the higher acuity of COVID-19 patients being treated at the listed facilities, the HFCs are struggling to meet the demand for dialysis and expect a continued increase over normal usage of between 25-50% 
NYS requesting extension of the following deployed resources:
Nassau University Hospital: 5 Tablo Dialysis Machines with associated consumables to perform treatments.
St John's Episcopal Hospital: 5 Tablo Dialysis Machines with associated consumables to perform for treatments.
Brookdale Hospital: 5 Tablo Dialysis Machines with associates consumables to perform treatments.
RRF notes date and time needed as 2/14/22 (or based on current contract dates)

At the direction of and in coordination with FEMA, HHS will deploy NDMS Disaster Medical Assistance Team (DMAT), National Veterinary Response Team (NVRT), Disaster Mortuary Operational Response Team (DMORT) medical response teams, personnel, and equipment to augment State and local medical response resources. NDMS team capabilities include the following:
Primary and acute care, mass casualties triage, initial resuscitation and stabilization, advanced life support, and preparing the sick or injured for evacuation
Veterinary medical services in support of ESF #11 for service and companion animals
Mortuary assistance to recover, identify, and process deceased victims
Mass casualty decontamination; medical triage following a nuclear, biological, and/or chemical incidents.
Teams are composed of non-Federal volunteers who are placed on intermittent Federal appointments to facilitate activation, when necessary. When activated, NDMS response team members are Federalized employees of the HHS. Teams are normally deployed for 10 to 14 days. Lease or purchase of accountable property: None FEMA logistical support needed: Teams may require some level of base operating support (food, shelter, laundry, etc.). MA task orders will be issued for specific personnel requirements, location(s), dates, and duration of assignment(s). All equipment and
supply purchases must be coordinated with FEMA. Prior FEMA approval is necessary to ensure reimbursement.

TRIBAL REQUEST: IHS Whiteriver Indian Hospital. The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), will assist the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), Indian Health Service (IHS) with COVID-19 outbreak response operations by providing staffing of healthcare personnel to support multiple IHS locations in Arizona to include the IHS Phoenix and Tucson Regional Areas. This initial request includes seven (7) Med Surge Registered Nurses (RNs), ten (10) ER Nurses and three (3) ICU Nurses per day, and two (2) Area Emergency Managers not to exceed the MA total estimated cost. The Teams will work IHS assigned schedules with a potential for 12 hours shifts and will be deployed to support IHS facilities, as required to include the Whiteriver Indian Hospital. The POC for IHS is Capt. David Cramer who will be directing the teams for the Regional Areas, his contact number is 1-602-717-8829. Services to be provided not to exceed 45 days. IHS will supply PPE for the duration of the mission. PPE will include gloves, N95 masks, surgical masks, disposable gowns, hair bonnets, booties, face shields and hand sanitizer. VHA Team will provide their own transportation.

Provide definitive care at NDMS hospitals for patients from Hurricane MARIA moved from affected areas by the National Disaster Medical System (NDMS). Care is to be provided by NDMS hospitals for patients regulated through activated Federal Coordinating Centers.
This MA replaces previously issued: 4340DR-VI-HHS-02 (1509-241535)

This is provided at 0% State Cost Share due to President Trump's Waiver, which states: I have determined that the damage in certain areas of the territory of the U.S. Virgin Islands resulting from Hurricane Maria beginning on September 16, 2017, and continuing, is of sufficient severity and magnitude that special cost sharing arrangements are warranted regarding Federal funds provided under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, 42 U.S.C. 5121 et seq. (the Stafford Act). 

Therefore, I amend my declaration of September 20, 2017, to authorize a 100 percent Federal cost share for debris removal and emergency protective measures, including direct Federal assistance, for 180 days from the start of the incident period, and a 90 percent Federal cost share thereafter.

The US Department of Transportation/Federal Highway Administration to provide supplemental personnel to the US Virgin Islands to complete Puerto Rico Division Office mission essential functions including damage assessments. 

Assessments of the road network and infrastructure are critical components of immediate response to allow for relief supplies to reach survivors and permit freedom of movement to essential services, such as medical care. There is an immediate need for additional qualified inspectors to complete the assessments. Existing staff within Puerto Rico are also survivors, experiencing critical shortfalls or food, drinking water, and fuel. FHWA PR Division Staff requires additional resources to fulfil this critical task as soon as possible. Activation of FHWA personnel for detailed assessments for determining long term restoration requirements and cost analysis will expedite assistance resources.

Request DOI deploy specialty Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) to provide expertise in support of FEMA response operations. The SMEs shall conduct damage surveys/assessments for the purpose of FEMA compliance with environmental and historic preservation laws, regulations, and executive orders. The SMEs will not be signing any Records of Environmental Considerations.

Subject Matter Experts shall include: Two (2) Secretary of Interior Professional Qualification Standards-qualified structural specialists (architectural historians) and three (3) historic preservation structural specialists (non-Secretary of Interior Qualification Standards-qualified is acceptable) and one (1) archaeologist, to do damage assessments/surveys for FEMA?s Office of Environmental Planning and Historic Preservation.

Six total staff are needed for a minimum of 60 days.
Additional staff may be authorized on this Mission Assignment per FEMA?s request.

FEMA is requesting up to 18 two to three-person teams comprised of civil engineers specializing in structures, geo-technical and heavy road construction. The inspection teams will work with the Bridge and Road Task Force to provide inspections and recommendations for emergency repairs or temporary bridges to restore the functionality or service to municipal roads required for evacuation routes or for essential river crossings with unreasonable detour routes. In addition, the teams will perform damage assessments and develop scopes of work and cost estimates for preparing the FEMA Public Assistance PW grants for funding the permanent repair or replacement of designated municipal (non-Federal Aid) roads and bridges damaged by the hurricanes and flooding, and eligible under the DR-4339-PR disaster declaration.

The United States Department of Transportation's Maritime Administration (USDOT/MARAD) will provide assistance to FEMA in soliciting and procuring commercial vessel ships for berthing missions in support of Hurricane Maria response.

Technical Assistance for Commercial Berthing Vessels 

As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, Dept of Transportation DOT/MARAD will provide technical expertise and acquisition  assistance to procure commercial vessels ships as a floating housing facility, billeting, meals, shipboard support and port services for Territory/FEMA approved personnel in support of Hurricane Maria response operations.  MARAD will issue a solicitation for berthing vessels with 4500 bed capacity for minimum 30 days operation with multiple  14 day extension options. MARAD will  identify viable commercial berthing vessel  options, develop estimates  and obtain FEMA concurrence before  entering into contracts for commercial berthing vessels.  FEMA will provide additional funds to enable MARAD to enter into  any such berthing vessel contract awards approved by MARAD. 

Start Date: October 3.

Seminole Tribe of Florida (STOF) is requesting medication and pharmacy supplies, listed in the attached document, delivered to STOF Pharmacy. Pharmacy lost power to their generator from impact of Hurricane Irma. Tribal resources in the short term are inadequate to address the needs of the community.

The Seminole Tribe of Florida (STOF) is requesting Ground and Air Mosquito Control and Abatement (barrier treatment/ adulticide) assistance on the Big Cypress and Brighton Reservations impacted by Hurricane Irma. 

The Big Cypress Reservation requires 38 miles of Adulticide: Riptide, and 10 miles of barrier treatment: Riptide. (Ground) 

The Big Cypress Reservation requires 12000 acres of Adulticide: Riptide, and 3000 acres of Lavicide: Spheratax. (Air) 

The Brighton Reservation requires 37 miles of Adulticide: Riptide, and 6 miles of barrier treatment: Riptide. (Ground) 

The Brighton Reservation requires 10500 acres of Adulticide: Riptide, and 2200 acres of Lavicide: Spheratax. (Air) 

The STOF lacks effective methods, techniques, equipment to control the mosquito population. The abatement is vital to negate mosquito-transmitted disease. This request is in conjunction with Seminole Tribe of Florida and Federal declarations of emergency. Tribal resources in the short term are unable to address the needs of the community. 

See the attached RRFs for Delivery locations

Request HHS alert and/or activate Veterans Administration (VA) Federal Coordinating Centers (FCCs) for patient medical evacuation in support of FEMA response operations.

As directed by and in coordination with FEMA, the HHS Patient Movement Coordinating Committee will alert and/or activate Veteran?s Administration (VA) Federal Coordination Centers (FCC?s) and their associated networks to prepare to receive and accept patients/casualties in support of FEMA response operations. As requested by the State of Texas, and in coordination vvith FEMA, ESF-10 personnel will conduct field operations, to include: identify and assess impacts to drinking water and wastewater critical infrastructure; assist in the implementation of Response Manager tracking system; emergency response to oil and hazardous materials discharges/ releases; and augmenting personnel for response operations. In addition, ESF-10 will conduct aerial assessments to assess discharges/ releases; accumulations of orphaned containers, and damages to oil/ chemical facilities. This information will be used to help ensure safety of response personnel entering into the impacted areas.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency is requesting federal operating support from the United States Army Corps of Engineers for infrastructure technical assessment needs.  The Key Allegro Bridge, owned by the City of Rockport, Texas, and located at: 28.049475, -97.031131, underwent structural damage during Hurricane Harvey to the extent that it is currently under load restrictions and is has a high risk potential of being compromised due to a noted loss of structural integrity.  The current bridge is the only ingress/egress route in place for Key Allegro to the mainland.  It is requested that a bridge technical assessment team deploy to the City of Rockport the week of 13 August 2018 to meet with local officials to discuss, assess, and support the development of a plan for an alternate ingress/egress route from Key Allegro to the City of Rockport.  The City has informed that the consideration is to place a temporary access route immediately to the west of the existing structure.  The City is requesting support for a best solution to allow traffic flow on and off Key Allegro for day-to-day transportation needs to include the provision of public goods and services and in support of the rebuild efforts ongoing on the Key due to the damage created by Hurricane Harvey.

Request the activation of the Emergency Prescription Assistance Program (EPAP). EPAP facilitate activities related to processing and payment of prescription drug claims for medications and durable medical equipment (DME) for designated eligible individuals in areas in which the President has declared an emergency or major disaster under the Stafford Act. DME covered under this program is available in many retail pharmacies and is relatively inexpensive. EPAP allows any enrolled pharmacy in the United States and its territories to use existing electronic pharmacy systems as an infrastructure to efficiently process prescriptions and DME specifically for the affected uninsured population.

The State of Tennessee is requesting mobile/portable wastewater treatment capabilities to be used in at Erwin Wastewater Treatment Plant, in Unicoi County.  Treatment capabilities are required for up to the design capacity of up to 2,000,000 million gallons per day and the hydraulic capacity of up to 8,000,000 gallons per day. The plant needs a chlorine contact chamber and aeration basin. The Erwin Wastewater Treatment plant primary grid remover and primary clarifier are salvageable and can be used. This request is for an extended period.  Damages to the Erwin Wastewater Treatment plant are catastrophic preventing the repair and utilization of existing wastewater treatment infrastructure (electrical and mechanical) due to flooding and debris.  Use of a mobile/portable wastewater system is a critical life safety and public health and medical issue. The local jurisdiction will provide security and personnel to assist with management, coordination, and oversight of the site as required.  The State of Tennessee does not have the capability or resources to address this critical request.

The State of Tennessee is requesting mobile/portable wastewater treatment capabilities to be used in at Erwin Wastewater Treatment Plant, in Unicoi County.  Treatment capabilities are required for up to the design capacity of up to 2,000,000 million gallons per day and the hydraulic capacity of up to 8,000,000 gallons per day. The plant needs a chlorine contact chamber and aeration basin. The Erwin Wastewater Treatment plant primary grid remover and primary clarifier are salvageable and can be used. This request is for an extended period.  Damages to the Erwin Wastewater Treatment plant are catastrophic preventing the repair and utilization of existing wastewater treatment infrastructure (electrical and mechanical) due to flooding and debris.  Use of a mobile/portable wastewater system is a critical life safety and public health and medical issue. The local jurisdiction will provide security and personnel to assist with management, coordination, and oversight of the site as required.  The State of Tennessee does not have the capability or resources to address this critical request. This MA replaces previous MA 3620EM-TN-COE-LRD-01

ARPA-HHS to provide NDMS HMTF to Research Medical Center for Emergency Department Decompression (EDD) and/or general hospital decompression as necessary for up to 30 days. To start NLT 07 Jan 2022.
- Assessment will be completed 10 days into the mission to determine if the team should be reloaded at 14 days.
- Cost Estimate
16 people
$2500/person for travel and per-diem
$1000/person per day
Up to 30 days. (each team can only come for 14 days)
Initial PPE push pack - $15,000
(32 people x $2500)+(16x$1000)30 days + 15,000 = $575,000

NDMS HMTF will be 16 people to include:
1 Group Supervisor
1 Log
1 Team Commander

In support of Virginia's request, as directed by and in coordination with FEMA, USACE will deploy the Debris PRT to coordinate and execute all necessary actions associated with debris clearance, removal, and/or disposal site management from public property in the affected areas necessary to eliminate or lessen immediate threats to public health and safety in support of STT disaster operations. This support may include debris clearance and removal from critical access routes, roads, bridges, waterways (outside of federal agency s authorities), and rights of way
for emergency vehicles and public access. This support may also include any or all
of the following: pickup, hauling, and dumping of debris; segregating and reducing
debris at a landfill or temporary disposal and reduction site (TDRS); hauling from a
TDRS to a final disposal site; or managing a TDRS. In limited instances, FEMA may
authorize private property debris clearance and removal and demolition as
necessary to eliminate or lessen immediate threats to public health and safety.
Logistics and/or real estate support for rights of entry and leasing may be
necessary. When there is Hazardous Toxic and Radioactive Waste (HTRW) and as
authorized by FEMA, USACE may activate and deploy the Contaminated Debris
Management PRT. USACE is responsible for providing personnel and/or equipment
necessary to accomplish the mission. FEMA will issue a Record of Environmental Consideration (REC) for work completed under this Mission Assignment; all work performed is subject to the conditions of the REC.
